result.heading: EVERYTHING YOU ARE ABOUT TO SEE, HAPPENED

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - PRE-DAWN A small, pleasant house on a tree-lined street in Los Angeles circa 1928. 210 North Avenue 23. Not far from Dodger Stadium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LOS ANGELES, MARCH 9, 1928.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - CHRISTINE'S BEDROOM - PRE-DAWN A Bakelite alarm clock hits 6:30 A.M. and RINGS. CHRISTINE COLLINS, thirties, attractive, rumpled, reaches INTO FRAME to shut it off. She sits up, rubs tiredly at her face, and moves
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: switching on a radio as she goes. Music fills the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws water on her face as the music continues. She looks at herself in the mirror as the light flickers overhead. She hits the wall offhandedly, something she does every day. The flickering stops. With a last look at the mirror, she smoothes back her hair and exits, switching off the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dressed now, she flicks on the overhead light. WALTER COLLINS is nine years old, with light brown hair, though we don't see much of it or him, he's entangled in the sheets. It's important that we don't see him too clearly in most of the following scenes, but without drawing attention to that aspect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits on the edge of the bed, runs a hand through his hair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter...time for school, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just ten more minutes -- CHRISTINE Sorry, champ. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, kisses him on the forehead, and exits. He sits on the edge of the bed, wavers, then falls back into bed again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) You can sleep in all you want tomorrow, that's what Saturdays are for. Now hurry up or your breakfast will get cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's cereal, it's supposed to be cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A street-car (known then as the Big Red) rumbles down the street in the gray light of morning, passing Ford Model A's and Hudsons and Nash four-door sedans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine sits on one of the benches, Walter's face buried in her lap, still half-asleep. She nudges him as they come to an intersection by a grade school. It's early enough that only a few other kids have arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him a sack lunch and follows as he slouches toward the door. She watches from the curb as he heads toward the school. Some of the teachers lounging outside nod to her as Walter approaches, so she knows they're aware that he's there. She waves, then hurriedly gets back on the street-car as it rumbles away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're here, sweetie.   Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Located on Grand Avenue downtown, the huge switchboard room is a maze of switching stations, tangles of wires and heavy wooden headsets...a roar of buzzers, bells, circuits opening and closing, and a hundred female operators speaking at once. Supervisors on skates roll up and down the narrow lanes created by the banks of switching stations, going from one operator to another as needed. Christine is one of them. She turns at the SOUND of a bell struck twice, then rolls down the lane toward an OPERATOR frantically waving a pink sheet of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mortified operator hands her the headset and stalks off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay Sandy, what's the prob--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine struggles on the headset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reacts to the phone being hung up hard at the other end as the floor manager, BEN HARRIS, 30s, approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She roller-skates off toward another operator waving another pink sheet of paper.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You deal with this one, I'm not going near it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello? Yes, this is the supervisor, ma'am, what can I -- (checks board) Yes, I can see that you're on a party line, ma'am, what can I -- (beat) I know, it's unfortunate, but people sometimes do listen in on party lines. We hope to have private lines installed by -- (beat) Well, what's he doing when you're on the phone? (beat) Are you sure? Maybe there's a problem with the phone line. He could be asthmatic, or -- (beat) Oh. No, I...I've never heard of anything like that before either. Guess there's a first time for everything, right? No, I'm afraid there's nothing we can do about people abusing the equipment or... themselves. I'm sorry. I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Everything all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, Mr. Harris...fine...just someone having a problem with a... with the connection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Tell them to take the plug and shove it in and out a few times, that'll usually do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unfortunately that was part of the problem. If you'll excuse me....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine sits alone, eating a bag lunch and reading a thick telephone company manual. Working hard to advance herself. Then a bell rings: time to return to work. Other employees gather up their belongings and start inside. As Christine closes the book, her bookmark falls out. As she picks it up, we see that it's a child's drawing: her and Walter (with arrows indicating who is who) on a green hill, under an orange sun. She touches the drawing and smiles as the bell rings again. She grabs her belongs and heads back inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine waits outside the school as another bell rings, announcing the end of classes. Kids run outside, Walter among them. He folds in alongside as they start down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, sport.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, mom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how was school?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. We learned about dinosaurs, and I got in a fight with Billy Mankowski.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He hit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you hit him back? (he nods) Good. Rule number one: Never start a fight, but always finish it. So why did he hit you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I hit him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait...you hit him first? (he nods) Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine takes his hand, and they continue down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and crouches down in front of him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He said my dad ran off because he didn't like me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your dad never even had a chance to meet you...so how could he not like you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why did he leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the same day you were born, something else arrived. It came in the mail, in a box just slightly bigger than you. You know what was in that box? (he shakes head) Something called responsibility. Now, to some people, responsibility is fun, it's what you live your whole life for. Other people think it's the scariest thing in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So he ran away because he was scared of what was in the box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's dumb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I thought.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Walter, I decided a long time ago that I would always tell you the truth, that I would treat you like a grown-up. I can't expect you to respect me unless I respect you. (beat) I've never lied to you. Your father leaving had nothing to do with you, and everything to do with what was in the responsibility box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pinky-swear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his pinky in hers, gives a tug.    He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs and tears off. She runs after him, letting him stay ahead of her the whole way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pinky-swear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First one to the corner store gets ice cream!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Walter is asleep on the floor, in front of the radio, which is playing the closing moments of Amos and Andy. Christine enters and turns off the radio. He stirs, looks up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks him up and carries him up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she disappears upstairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did I miss Amos and Andy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid so, sport.   Come on now, time for bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are we still going to the movies tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. I hear there's a new Charlie Chaplin playing down at Grauman's, and a new serial called The Mysterious Airman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Nobody does. That's what makes him so mysterious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.   Am I too heavy for you to carry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not for years yet, Walter.     Not for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - MORNING Just enough to bring us into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - CHRISTINE'S BEDROOM - MORNING She's getting ready for the day and is almost out of the room when the phone rings. She hesitates, then picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MARCH 10, 1928 CHRISTINE Hello? (beat) Oh, hello, Margaret. I'm fine, thanks. No, I was just -- (beat) You're kidding. When did she call in sick? (checks watch) What about Myrna? I know she could use the extra hours. Oh. No, it's just...I promised Walter I'd take him to the movies today. There has to be somebody else.... (beat) All right, I...guess we can do it tomorrow. I'll get there as soon as I can. But just until four, okay? See you in a bit. She hangs up. She doesn't like this, but there's no way out of it. She straightens and heads out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER A disappointed Walter sits on the couch as Christine puts things together quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops in front of him, kneels down to eye height.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's a sandwich and milk in the icebox, and I've asked Mrs. Riley if her daughter can stop by in a couple of hours, just to -- WALTER I can take care of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you can. She's coming by to check on the house, not you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow, we'll go to the movies. Then we'll ride the Big Red down to Santa Monica and walk on the pier. How's that? That okay? (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She heads out, the screen door clattering shut behind her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) (he nods) Good. I'll be back before it gets dark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not afraid of the dark.     I'm not afraid of anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you're not, honey. That's how I raised you. (kisses his head) Be good. See you in a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - CONTINUOUS She crosses the lawn and turns at the sidewalk, glancing back as Walter looks out at her from the window. She waves. He waves back. With one last look, she continues off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the place was hectic before, now it's even worse: lines buzzing, voices chattering, operators following Christine around with papers and question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine glances up at the clock, 4:39.    She's already late. But she does what's necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hurries off to take care of it all, the others following.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've got lines jammed from here to Ohio...he insists on talking to someone in charge...I've tried everything and the console's just dead...I need your signature here for a supply requisition....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, get me the Omaha routing station, see if we can put the calls through their switchers...and let's get that console running....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on a clock which reads 5:20, then TILT DOWN as Christine comes out of the switchboard room, pulling on a sweater, ready to leave...as the floor manager steps out of his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances down the block. The street car is approaching, but she doesn't want to piss off her boss by running off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks up to see the streetcar right at the stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She races out to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Christine...good, I was hoping to catch you. I've been following your work reports, and I just want you to know that I'm very impressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS When I first suggested hiring female supervisors, my superiors weren't big on the idea. But you've held your own as well as any of our male supervisors, and -- CHRISTINE Thank you, Mr. Harris, but I -- MR. HARRIS Ben, please. Point is, we're looking for someone to take on a managerial position in our new Beverly Hills office. If you're interested I can -- CHRISTINE That's great, Mr. Harris, I really appreciate the vote of confidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Good, good...so maybe we could --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, but I really have to go. We'll talk on Monday. Good night!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: running after the streetcar as it closes its doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the streetcar rumbles away before she can catch it. Frustrated, she glances at her watch and sighs resignedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait...wait...hold on, just a --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine sits on the front bench, watching as the shadows lengthen, then pulls the bell. The car rumbles to a stop as she steps out onto the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She passes a grocery store, where a clock reads 6:15, and continues past other houses on the pleasant, green street. We HEAR parents telling their kids to come in for dinner, radios playing music or radio dramas. Peaceful, charming. Christine smiles, turns the corner, looks to her house -- -- and it's dark, closed up. No lights on inside, no music or dramas on the radio. Dead silent. Christine pauses, then picks up her pace. No need to panic, he could be upstairs asleep, could be in the back of the house, where the lights wouldn't show. She goes to the front door.     It's unlocked.    She enters -- INT. COLLINS HOME - LIVING ROOM - EVENING It's dark, silent.    She puts her purse down.     Looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing.   She goes into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: switching on lights as she goes. Nothing. She checks the refrigerator. The sandwich she made Walter is untouched. She moves to the staircase.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She opens the door to his room.      No Walter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She crosses to the sidewalk.     Looks up and down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little GIRL on a tricycle rolls past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl continues away. Christine's concerned, but she hasn't hit the panic button, not yet. She crosses the street to -- CHANGELING A True Story
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter?   Honey? Time to come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Susie honey, have you seen Walter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nuh-uh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and rings the doorbell.       The door opens and MRS. RILEY, forties, emerges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine heads away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Riley, I'm sorry to bother you at dinnertime, but I was wondering if Walter was here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . RILEY No, I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know if Jamie was able to look in on him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . RILEY Well, I mentioned it to her, but she was going to a dance with some of her friends...you know how teenagers are. Is everything all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure it's fine, I just... (beat) Thank you, Mrs. Riley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine stops at the sidewalk in front of her house, looks up and down the street, arms folded against the growing chill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts walking again. Faster now. Looking around trees and porches, anywhere a nine-year-old boy might hide. She hears children playing. Laughing. She picks up her pace, homing in on the sound. She turns the corner to find three children playing, none of them Walter. She looks down the ominously empty streets. Her worry growing, she heads to the house.       Faster now.   Heels clicking on the hard sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter...?     Walter....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She bursts in, leaving the door open, looking around in case he came in while she was out. Nothing. She crosses to the phone, hesitates for just a BEAT, then picks up the receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a long pause as she waits, looks out the window, then:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Operator, give me the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Lincoln Heights Division.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, hello, my name is Christine Collins, I live at 210 North Avenue
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm calling to report a missing child...it's my son, he....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) How long has he been gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure...I just got home from work and...it could be since late this morning, it could be just an hour -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Have you checked around the neighborhood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course, I -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Maybe he lost track of the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he always stays around the house when it starts to get dark. Can you please send someone down here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) I'm sorry, but our policy is that we don't dispatch units on missing child cases for twenty-four hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?   But that's -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Ninety-nine times out of a hundred the kid shows up by morning. We don't have the resources to go chasing every kid who runs off with his pals and -- CHRISTINE That's not Walter, he doesn't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) With all due respect, ma'am, every parent who calls us says the same thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, I -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) I'm sorry, but there's nothing I can do. I'll take your name and information, but that's all until tomorrow morning at the earliest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine walks down the street, arms wrapped around herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues on, calling Walter's name as she disappears into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I'm sure he'll show up by then. They always do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - LIVING ROOM - MORNING Christine watches out the curtained living room windows, eyes red rimmed from worry but not from tears, not yet, as a police car finally pulls up. Neighbors look on as the officers get out and approach the house. HOLD on Christine's face, pale and worried, UNDER:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. ST. PAUL'S PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH - DAY Located at 5100 Coliseum Street
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (V.O.) Our thoughts go out again to Mrs. Christine Collins, of Lincoln Heights --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (V.O.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: whose young son, Walter Collins, disappeared almost two weeks ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PAUL'S CHURCH - DAY A large radio microphone with the call letters KGF is atop a podium, where PASTOR GUSTAV BRIEGLEB stands: fifties, barrel chested, no-nonsense, a fire-and-brimstone preacher. His congregation sits in hard wooden pews, listening and nodding.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Though she is not a member of our congregation, we pray for her today (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's APPLAUSE and cheering from the pews.   He lets it pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The place erupts into applause and cheering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) as we have every day since we first learned of her situation on the radio, and in the newspapers. (beat) We are told that the Los Angeles Police Department is doing the best it can to reunite mother and child, and I am sure that is true. (beat) But given its position as the most violent, corrupt and incompetent police department this side of the Rocky Mountains, that's not saying a great deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Every day, new bodies show up along Mulholland, or in ditches, the work of Police Chief James Davis and his so-called "gun squad." Every day the needs of honest citizens are put second to greed and personal gain. Every day, the city sinks deeper into a cesspool of fear, intimidation and corruption. Once the City of Angels, Los Angeles is now a place where our protectors have become our brutalizers...where to be the law...is to be above the law...where none dare speak truth to power. (beat) But we will not be silent. We will continue to put their offenses and their failures in full view of the public. We will not be intimidated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAVIS, 40s, hard-edged and tall, stands looking out the window as the radio drones on behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (on radio) Because while the "gun squad" speaks in the only language Chief Davis understands, we speak in the language of compassion, truth and strength. We speak for our fellow citizens, beaten and killed by a renegade police department. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More cheers and applause as Davis switches off the radio.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (on radio) (Cont'd) We speak for an innocent child, ripped from his mother's arms, now all but forgotten by the police. And that voice, my friends, will never be silenced.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - CHRISTINE'S BEDROOM - MORNING The alarm goes off, but Christine is already awake. Staring up at the ceiling. She slowly pulls herself up and moves OS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : APRIL 3, 1928 INT. WALTER'S BEDROOM - MORNING Christine walks past the door to his bedroom. Looks inside. Goes over to the bed. Her hand lingers, touching it, UNDER:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS (V.O.) Are you sure you're ready for this, Christine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine and Mr. Harris, the floor manager, approach the doors to the switchboard room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles as he says it, but there's the sense that he doesn't think Walter's coming back. It's been too long. She senses it, but moves past it, pushing open the door and entering
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS I mean, if you need more time -- CHRISTINE The police are doing all they can, and frankly I could use the money. It's been almost a month, and...it wouldn't do any good to find Walter and bring him home if he doesn't have a home to come back to, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As loud as before...until the operators see Christine, and the noise stops. She tries to smile, as if to say, I'm okay, but can't quite manage it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Several women approach and hug her as the noise level begins to climb, but nowhere near what it was a moment earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods as he exits, then heads off herself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Well...I'll leave you to it, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine moves from station to station, the noise level still noticeably low. Every time she approaches an operator, they lower their voices, as if not to bother her. One operator holds up a pink request sheet. Christine starts toward her, but then the operator glances to another supervisor and hands it off. Knowing she has to do something about this, she turns to the room and, in a firm, clear voice, says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room grows quiet.   Everyone is looking at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She manages a thin smile as the place returns to normal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, can I have your attention?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, everyone, I appreciate your consideration, but I'm not made of porcelain. I won't break down and cry if the station to station call to Kankakee doesn't go through. (a thin smile) Actually, I...promised myself that I wouldn't cry...wouldn't let myself cry...until I knew, one way or another, what.... (beat) Point is...I like the noise here. So don't be afraid to talk and...push buttons, and drop things. If it wasn't noisy, how would I know I was in the right place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mr. Harris steps out into the lunch area where a number of the operators and supervisors are hanging out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods his thanks, and continues off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARRIS Excuse me, has anyone seen Christine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I saw her in the back office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As before, Christine hurries from one station to another, lost in the barely-managed chaos. She slows, unable to look away, a growing dread settling in her heart. Harris points out the window. Points...to her. The police captain nods and enters the switchboard room. As Jones heads for her, the strength goes out of Christine's legs. She holds onto the a desk as he stops before her.

dialogue.raw_text: I was wrong to yell at you. You're still a child, and I think you don't really understand what you're doing, the hurt you're causing. Maybe this is all just some big game of pretend to you, but I need you to understand. Walter is...he's all I have, he's everything to me, and every day we lose because of this puts him further away from where I can help him. (beat) Whatever the police think, whatever the world thinks, we know the truth, don't we? We both know you're not Walter. Getting you to admit that may be the only chance I have to straighten this out before it's too late. Maybe you're afraid of getting in trouble, that you're in too deep. But you're not. You don't have to tell me who you are, you just have to tell them who you're not. Just... tell them the truth.

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (O.S.) When Chief Davis took over the LAPD two years ago, he said -- DAVIS (overlapping) We will hold court on gunmen in the Los Angeles streets. I want them brought in dead, not alive, and I will reprimand any officer who shows the least mercy to a criminal.

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB (V.O.) He picked fifty of the most dangerous cops on the force, gave them machine guns and permission to shoot anyone who got in their way. He called them the Gun Squad. No lawyers. No trials. No questions, suspensions or investigations. Just piles of bodies.

She runs her finger over it, tracing the impression left by his pencil. She starts to cry, and a tear falls onto the pencil drawing. dialogue.raw_text: Good morning. My name is Christine Collins. On March 10th, my nine year old son, Walter Collins, disappeared. A four month investigation resulted in a boy being brought to Los Angeles from De Kalb, Illinois. They told me, and all of you, that this boy was my son. They were wrong. (beat) The Los Angeles Police Department made a mistake...a terrible mistake. The boy they found is not my son. That is the reason for the supposed "transformation." I have letters from his dentist, his teachers and others confirming that this boy is not my son. The letters are being reprinted now, and I should have them for you tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have given the police department every opportunity to admit their mistake and renew the search for my son. Since they have refused to do so, I have no choice but to present my case before the public. I hope this will persuade the police to finish the job they started, and bring my son home to me. (beat) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what your problem is? You want to shirk your responsibilities as a mother. You enjoyed being a free woman, didn't you? Enjoyed not having to worry about a young son. You could do what you wanted, go where you wanted, see anyone you wanted. But then we found your son. Brought him back. And now he's an inconvenience. That's why you cooked up this whole scheme, to try and throw him to the state, let the state raise him for you.

Reaches for the doorknob...as suddenly a clock CHIMES loudly and the closet explodes outward and -- -- SANFORD CLARK, 15, runs out. He slams into Ybarra, knocking him down. They go down in a tumble of limbs, wrestling on the floor as Sanford tries to escape.

You're here on a code twelve, police action. The doctors, the staff, they figure that if the police sent you here, there must be a good reason for it.

dialogue.raw_text: Then I'll just have to prove that I'm not insane.

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? How? The more you try to act sane, the crazier you start to look. If you smile too much, you're delusional or stifling hysteria. If you don't smile, you're depressed. If you're neutral you're emotionally withdrawn and potentially catatonic.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have. Don't you get it? You're code twelve. So am I. We're here for the same reason. (beat) We pissed off the cops.

dialogue.raw_text: What about you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...work nights. (Chris doesn't get it) I mean, I work nights. Downtown. In some of the clubs. You know.

And sometimes, like when they say something that's a little, y'know, inconvenient...they just go fucking nuts, pardon my French. If we're insane, nobody has to listen to us. I mean, who are you going to believe, some crazy woman trying to destroy the integrity of the force, or a police officer? Then once they get us in here, we either learn to behave, and shut up, or -- (beat) Or you don't go home...or you go home like that.

dialogue.raw_text: Which is why I'm doing this pro bono. (a smile) It would be my honor to defend your honor, Mrs. Collins. In my fifteen years as a lawyer, I have never seen anyone fight as long or as hard as you have, in what is so clearly in the cause of justice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Now I want you to tell Mr. Hahn here the whole story, from end to end, leave nothing out, he'll need it all if he's going to get the City Council involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. One thing, though. A personal favor. When we've finished here today, could you spare a few minutes to come with me downtown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.     Where downtown?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hahn marches into the receiving area with Christine Collins and Briegleb. He goes to the receiving nurse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sees Christine Collins and the sentence dies midway. Hahn pulls out a handful of papers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?   May I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is S. S. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse exchanges a sour look with Christine and heads off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) Hahn, and I have a court order for the immediate release of all women being detained in this institution under the designation Code Twelve pending a formal inquiry into the reasons for their detainment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, but the doctor in charge won't be in until tomorrow morning and -- HAHN Let me be clearer. Either you open those doors and produce the people named in that court order, or you will find yourself on the other side of those bars...without a key.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: One by one, the Code Twelve patients are brought out of the hospital and into the light. One of the last to emerge is Carol Dexter, who blinks against the light, and sees Christine. She runs to her, embraces her, sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in Christine's face, we see a flicker of pride and one simple truth: if she could not save her son, she could at least save these women. As they move toward her, Hahn and Briegleb, we HEAR a TRAIN WHISTLE that segues us into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you'd come...I knew you'd come back...I knew you'd come....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right...everything's going to be all right now....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gordon Northcott, handcuffed, is led out of a train by several officers. The waiting PRESS rush toward him. He seems to enjoy the attention. Among the shouted questions we hear:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Northcott, any comment on your arrest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm feeling fine. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And on that the police hustle Gordon away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) I've been on a little vacation, as some of you know. It was a pleasant vacation, and the police have certainly provided me with a lot of amusement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you avoid capture?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I didn't, did I? Didn't know anyone wanted me until just recently. Didn't even try. My luggage still has my initials on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know why the police were after you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I figured it would be best if I stayed out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything to say to the parents of the children you murdered?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No comment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Davis is filling out paperwork as the door opens. He looks up as LOS ANGELES MAYOR GEORGE CRYER enters, closing the door after him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops a series of court documents on Davis' desk.   He picks them up, examines them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mayor Cryer...this is unexpected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So was this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Subpoenas, requests for depositions, interrogatories...all courtesy of Mr. Hahn and his new client, Christine Collins. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cryer shakes his head, walks off a pace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) You don't have to look them over too closely, Chief, your own copies should be arriving any time now. (beat) The City Council has also agreed to look into this, starting immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamnit....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought this was supposed to go away. This is an election year, I can't afford this kind of press.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is going away, sir.   I instructed Captain Jones -- CRYER I'm afraid falling on his sword and saying he made a mistake isn't going to be good enough, Chief. If we take him out of the picture for a while, it might help calm things down until the hearing's finished. (beat) There are several people on the council who are planning to run against me, and they'd love to accuse me of allowing a renegade police force to operate with impunity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our friends in the press are having a field day with this mess. I'm getting five hundred phone calls, letters and telegrams a day demanding to know what the hell is going on at City Hall that we allow our police force to brutalize women and misplace children. Christ, all this picture needs now is for somebody to kick a puppy for the cameras. (beat) This is a train, Chief, and we need to either get in front of it, or be run over by it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mayor Cryer...I stand by my men. You know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets the question sit as we go to
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I do. And you know where I stand. So the question is..are we going to stand together...or hang together?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mayor Cryer stands beside Chief Davis and addresses a rather noisy and worked-up press corps from behind a podium.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen...gentlemen, please. As Mayor of Los Angeles, it is my duty to preserve the peace in our city, which has been disrupted by recent events in the case of Christine Collins. As a result, we have decided that Captain J. J. Jones of the Lincoln Heights Division is to be suspended from active duty, effective immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the charge, Chief?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The charge is conduct unbecoming an officer, and using improper and abusive language toward Mrs. Collins. It further charges that he exceeded his authority as a police officer by incarcerating Mrs. Collins on the alleged charge of insanity without sufficient cause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mayor Cryer, are you aware that the City Council has said it plans to open its own investigation into the Collins case?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard this, yes. But since one of the main purposes of such a hearing by the City Council would be to suspend Captain Jones, and since that action has now been taken, the question is moot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which makes it look like the only reason Jones is being suspended is to head off the City Council (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two head back into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) investigation. Are you concerned that an outside investigation might go uncomfortably high up the food chain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't even dignify that question with a response. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Glancing back over their shoulders at the press outside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cheer up, Chief. That little show should take the wind out of their sails. By Monday, this issue will be as cold as yesterday's fish. Never underestimate the public's lack of attention and potential for apathy. Old news is dead news, you'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She opens the door as Briegleb enters with three really large, dangerous looking men, one of whom is carrying a heavy trench coat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Reverend, what -- BRIEGLEB Sorry to barge in so late, Mrs. Collins, but it took me a while to find the right people for the right job. These three gentlemen are members of my congregation who, before coming to the Lord, had lived lives of brutality, vice and crime. Now they are pledged to doing god's work...and if this isn't it, I don't know what is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People who bring charges against the police have a habit of (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others nod as they make themselves comfortable in the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She heads off to get some coffee. As one of the men puts his coat behind the sofa, we see that it contains a sawed-off shotgun. Briegleb looks out the window, to where a police car sits, watching the house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) disappearing right before the trial. I'm a big believer in the power of prayer, Mrs. Collins...but a little backup from time to time never hurts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see...well, I...thank you.   Can I get you anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since we don't plan on sleeping, coffee would be lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She's dressed in her best dress, putting on a hat and a pair of gloves. Her hands are shaking. She squeezes them together, closes her eyes. Focuses. With one final, deep breath, she heads out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLLINS HOME - MORNING The same police car is there as Christine gets into a car with Briegleb and the two drive off. The other three men get into another car and follow. The police car in turn pulls away from the curb, following both cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's aware that they're being followed, glancing in the rear view mirror to keep an eye on things. Looks over to Christine, smiles encouragingly. Looks ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns. The other cars do the same. But the traffic here is even worse. Just then, Briegleb looks back in his rear view mirror to see -- -- another police car pulling out of a driveway and cutting off the car with Christine's bodyguards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Traffic's getting heavy.   We'll go up Spring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Briegleb turns quickly, trying to get ahead, but the street's too busy. He looks in the mirror to see that another police car glide into position two cars behind them. Traffic stops. Jammed. Briegleb is nervous, sensing the very real possibility of a hit being set up. The traffic is lined right up against parked cars on either side. Then there's a momentary break in traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns hard into the driveway of a closed shop and shuts off the engine. Jumps out and opens the door for Christine, who gets out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do. He glances back at the police car. The two inside start to open the doors, but they can't get them open, being right up against parked cars on one side and traffic on the other. They run the siren to clear traffic, but it's too late as -- -- Christine and Briegleb hurry down the street on foot, Briegleb glancing behind them. The foot- and car-traffic is very heavy...we HEAR horns honking and, in the distance, something that could be the sound of lots of people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Briegleb glances back. The police car has popped its doors, and two trench-coated officers are getting out. Christine stops a man passing in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Start walking. Quickly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Almost there. Just a few more blocks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is all this traffic's coming from...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, can you tell me what the problem is up ahead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you hear? It's the biggest protest I've ever seen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Protest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...over that Collins broad, if you can believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves on. Briegleb and Collins slowly exchange a look somewhere between disbelief and "oh shit."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk quickly up one clogged street and down another, the police following on foot...moving toward the SOUND of voices, drums, and cars honking... until they turn onto Spring Street -- -- and find themselves in the middle of the biggest protest march ever recorded in the history of Los Angeles to this date. Thousands of people crowd into the street, overwhelming the police presence...not rioting, but making their voices heard. The Salvation Army, the Women's Temperance Society, the Society for Justice, Catholic groups, Union groups and ordinary citizens carrying placards and signs that read WE SUPPORT CHRISTINE COLLINS and JUSTICE FOR MRS. COLLINS and THE LAPD:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't mean...he couldn't mean -- REV. BRIEGLEB I don't know...all I know is that I think I just stopped breathing....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...it just goes on and on and on. Christine looks out to see her boss from the telephone company, Mr. Harris, marching arm in arm with the rest. He sees her, smiles, tips his hat and continues marching. Christine is stunned...Briegleb even moreso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks behind them, to where the police have stopped. There's no way in hell they can make a move in the face of something as big as t his. Briegleb smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue up the street toward City Hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB The Lord works in mysterious ways, Mrs. Collins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRIEGLEB Boy howdy, does He ever.   Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Ladies and Gentlemen...can I have your attention, please....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This is a big room, and one thousand observers fill every available chair with more standing along the wall in back. It's a circus. Christine sits with Hahn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Briegleb is in a seat behind the main section.    FLASHBULBS pop as THORPE, a city councilman, speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OCTOBER 24, 1928 THORPE There are nearly one thousand people gathered in this chamber, more than have ever been in this room before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speakers are lowered from the window into the parking lot where hundreds of others are gathered to listen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on pa) I therefore ask you to refrain from demonstrations of any kind. We're all here because we want to find out the real facts in this case, and everybody is going to be heard if we have to sit here for a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Thorpe looks to the other members of the Council, and the area where witnesses are supposed to wait to be called upon. A number of seats are empty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Thorpe, I don't see any other members of the Police Commission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's odd...we specifically stipulated that we would begin our hearings with testimony from the police department. Are there any representatives of the Police Commission in the room? (no answer) Is Chief Davis here? (no reply) Is Captain Jones here? Is there anyone here representing the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: raises his hand, then stands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Chairman...Richard Thomas, The Evening Herald. Both the Police Chief and Captain Jones are in San Pedro for a police inspection at a station there. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's APPLAUSE from the crowd which breaks up into pockets of discussion as a BAILIFF approaches Hahn and whispers into his ear. Hahn nods, looks to Christine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puzzled, curious, Christine gets up and exits with Hahn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) Only reason I know is we have a couple of our boys out covering the thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you telling me they directly violated the wishes of the City Council? That they refused to attend a vital hearing so they could conduct a routine inspection in San Pedro? And what the hell is Jones doing at an inspection after being suspended? (beat) I hate to call a recess before we've even started, but I think a few phone calls are in order. So we'll take a half hour break, then continue with the witnesses who have appeared here today. But let it be known that Captain Jones and Police Chief Davis will be subpoenaed and required to appear here tomorrow morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Collins, could you come across the street with me for just a moment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But...shouldn't we -- HAHN I think there's something you should see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hahn is moving quickly down the hall toward a courtroom door, Christine following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets to the door, pauses. Looks back to her.    She nods. He opens the door and they enter
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: the police decided it was best to keep this off the main docket in order to avoid exactly the sort of chaos we have across the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead silence, in marked contrast to the city council room. As she enters, she sees people sitting silently in the gallery...row after row of couples, mothers and fathers, some weeping softly. Some of them notice Christine's entrance and nod to her with sadness and a strange sense of common bond...they are all carrying the same grief. One of the couples, MR. AND MRS. CLAY, see Christine and go to her, speaking softly. They should be distinct enough in appearance that we will recognize them instantly when we see them again later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods her thanks as a door at the other end of the courtroom opens. They take their seats as a judge and two attorneys take their places, preceded by a bailiff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do. The judge takes his seat. The rest of the room also sits. He nods to the bailiff, who in turn opens another door, leading to the holding area. As Christine looks on, Gordon Stewart Northcott is ushered into the courtroom for his initial plea. Some women break into tears at the sight of him. He first seems startled by the presence of so many, then he smiles. An audience. As he takes his place beside his attorney, he looks down the room and meets the gaze of Christine Collins. Her face pales, as though slapped...but she doesn't look away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bailiff forcibly turns him around to face the judge. Christine's hands grip the seat she's in until her knuckles turn white...but she doesn't allow him the satisfaction of seeing her react to his comments. The judge looks up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . CLAY Mrs. Collins? I'm Leanne Clay, this is my husband, John...I just wanted to pass on my sympathies. What we went through, waiting to hear anything about our son David, was bad enough, and now this.... (beat) But there was no call for what the police did to you...no call at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All rise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey...I saw you in the papers. You got a lot of moxie, standing up to the police like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances back at his audience.   The bailiff rights him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bailiff removes Gordon, who shares one last look with his audience, and Christine in particular. He winks at her. She doesn't give him a flicker of satisfaction with a reaction. But once he's gone, she sits heavily and covers her eyes, fighting tears. Hahn puts a hand on her shoulder, but says nothing. There's nothing to say.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gordon Stewart Northcott, you have been charged with three counts of murder in the first degree, with an additional seventeen counts under review by the district attorney's office. How do you plea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not guilty, your honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In light of the defendant's penchant for international travel, no bail will be set. This court will receive preliminary motions by tomorrow morning, with a trial date to be set for the earliest opening on the court's calendar. (beat) The defendant is remanded into custody. Bailiff....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The boy, Walter Collins, was reported as missing on March 10, 1928.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jones is at last on the stand. Hahn stands before him, the rest of the City Council, Christine and the huge audience looking on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We then instituted a nationwide search. On July 10, we received a cable indicating that a boy matching his description had been found in De Kalb, Illinois. Upon questioning, he admitted to being Walter Collins, and we made arrangements to transport him back to California.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where Mrs. Collins told you the boy was not her son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hahn turns away, playing to the council and the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd applauds and cheers.    Joes fights to be heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. She denied his identity in spite of all evidence pointing to the contrary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But as subsequent events have demonstrated, she was correct. So what prompted you to send her for psychological evaluation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whether or not this was in fact the correct boy was not relevant to my decision. Throughout this period, she acted strangely. She was often cool, aloof and unemotional, especially when presented with the boy we located in De Kalb, and in our subsequent conversations. It was because of her disturbing behavior that I submitted her for observation to the psychopathic ward of Los Angeles County General Hospital.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just like that. You snap your fingers and an innocent woman is thrown into the psycho ward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She wasn't --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every home in this state is in grave danger when a Police Captain can take a woman into his office and, five minutes later, have her thrown into the psychopathic ward on his own authority!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over the crowd) She wasn't -- HAHN What was that, Captain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She wasn't thrown.     She was... escorted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's laughter from the gallery.   He doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hahn goes to the exhibit table, picks up several papers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Escorted, thrown, the verb doesn't matter, Captain. What does matter is that her incarceration was ordered without a warrant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am holding a carbon copy of the affidavit of insanity that was issued in the case of the State of California vs. Christine Collins. Who signed the affidavit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what is the date on this document?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: September 12th.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Mrs. Collins was incarcerated on September 6th.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The form is backdated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, so it would appear. The bottom of the page is reserved for recording where and when the warrant was served. But it has not been filled in. May I assume from this that the warrant was never served?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's correct. There was no need to serve the warrant since she was at that time already in custody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me see if I have this straight. A woman was thrown into the psychopathic ward without a warrant, because no warrant existed, and when it was finally written six days later, there was no need to sign it or go to a judge because (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this correct, Captain?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More murmuring from the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This silences both Jones and the crowd. You could hear a pin drop. Hahn approaches Jones, and now speaks softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jones looks to Chief Davis.   It's a moment.    Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine's face falls into her hands.   The place erupts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) she was already in the asylum!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Technically...yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Extraordinary steps were necessary because we were dealing with an extraordinary situation! Is it our fault that we were being deceived by the boy who claimed to be Walter Collins? No. In light of his claims and her behavior, who wouldn't begin to wonder if there was something wrong with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because she questioned you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because she wouldn't listen, because she insisted on being obstinate and taking matters into her own hands best left to qualified officers, because -- HAHN Because she was fighting for the life of her son! A boy who may have still been alive while you were wasting valuable time denying you had done anything wrong!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And in the end, that's what happened, isn't it? At some point, while all this was going on, Walter Collins died along with as many as nineteen other youths on the Northcott Ranch in Wineville. Is that correct, Captain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.   It is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hahn walks away from a devastated looking Jones.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No further questions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A small crowd is assembled at the front of the station, where Chief Davis stands with the Boy who had been "Walter" as a train pulls up before them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, he turns as a Matron comes off the train with JANET HUTCHINS, middle thirties, the boy's mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to him and hugs him. "Walter" looks like he wishes he were somewhere on Mars. Davis moves closer to them to be in frame while the FLASHBULBS pop. She's in the same pose as they got Christine to take when she "accepted" her lost son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He towsels the boy's head like he'd like to cut it off. Then he nods to an aide, who approaches with a bundle of clothes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: so after much effort, we were able to identify this boy, who was has been responsible for so much recent trouble, as Arthur Hutchins of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Between this, and the arrest of the man suspected of murdering the real Walter Collins, we have cleared up two of the biggest mysteries in the history of Los Angeles. (beat) I hope that you gentlemen of the press will give as much space to the good things we do as the mistakes that are made on rare occasions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me introduce you to the boy's real mother, Mrs. Janet Hutchins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope he hasn't been too much trouble for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, not at all....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Hutchins...Mrs. Collins, the woman he was staying with, wanted him to have these. They're the clothes she let him wear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story

direction.raw_text: EXT. NORTHCOTT RANCH - FLASHBACK - NIGHT David is shoved into the chicken coop. Several other BOYS are already there, scared, crying. They lunge at the door, trying to get out, but it slams shut in their faces. They scream, trying to get out.   Gordon SLAMS an arm against the door, scaring them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs and moves off, Sanford accompanying him, looking very guilty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, so after you got into the car, what happened next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They drove me around for a long time, then we ended up at this ranch --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! (grinning) I'll see you boys later....
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Were there other boys present?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah...six, I think. It was a long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Did you speak to them? Do you remember any of their names?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NING the boys huddled against one wall, scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We STOP PAN on the last kid...on Walter Collins, at last.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah...two of them were brothers, I think their last name was Winslow, something like that. The oldest was Jeffrey, I think he was around eleven.... (beat) ...and Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Christine REACTS to this, her hand flying to her mouth. Not daring to breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christine covers her face.     Can barely stand up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you remember his last name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Collins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So if you only remember some of the names of the rest, how come you remember his full name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because of what happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two of the kids, Walter and Jeffrey, are sitting in a corner, talking quietly, urgently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pull at the wiring.    Part of the roof weakens and dust sifts down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CHANGELING A True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in an echo of what he told his mother the last time he saw her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Winslow kids nod, and start crying.   Jeffrey and Walter look to the rest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David holds up his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Winslow boys and two others scramble to the other end, too terrified to try and escape. Jeffrey, David and Walter go to the weakened corner of the coop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They nod, and get into position, each taking a part of the wire framework.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do so, pulling for all they're worth...struggling...the ceiling SHIFTS above them, dirt falling all over the place... they pull harder, the wire cutting into fingers, but still pulling...then suddenly -- -- the corner FALLS AWAY, part of the roof starting to come down with it. The NOISE is substantial.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Walter and Jeffrey were talking when everybody else was screaming. They were scared, same as the rest of us, but they weren't scared stupid. They kept checking around until they found a part of the coop where the chicken wire was all messed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) They figured we might be able to yank the chicken wire and bring down the corner, maybe make enough room to get out of there and run... but it would make an awful lot of noise and if it wasn't wide enough, we'd be stuck. It might even bring the whole place down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gotta try it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!   What he hears --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to get out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not. I'm not afraid of anything. (beat) Don't you want to go home? Don't you want to see your mom again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Anybody who doesn't want to come, get over at that end in case this comes down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When we get out, we split up, go in different directions, they can't catch all of us. Ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pull!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They race out the opening, Jeffrey first, then Walter, then David...but just as the first two get clear -- DAVID Help! Walter turns to see David stuck in the wiring. LIGHTS go on around the ranch. He hesitates...then RUNS back to David, helps to untangle him. They HEAR a SHOTGUN blast, and FEET running their way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walter gets him untangled, and the two RACE away from the coop, running for all they're worth as a FLASHLIGHT hits first one, then the other. They RUN -- -- and David catches one last glimpse of Walter running, heading for the line of trees....
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And that's the last you saw of him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the interview continues.   David nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's the last I saw of any of 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you don't know if either of the other two were captured?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. All I know is, if he hadn't come back for me...I don't think I ever would've gotten out of there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened after that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hid in the woods for two days, too scared to move, because I was sure they'd find me. I finally started walking, but every time a car came up I was afraid it was them. So I kept off the main roads until I saw a train stopped at a crossing, and I jumped in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David looks away, his eyes tearing up.   Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it's all Mrs. Clay can take. Sobbing, she runs out of the viewing room and into the interview room, where she goes to her son and embraces him, holds him, the two crying into one another's arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you tell anyone what had happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was afraid! I thought they'd come after me, or my folks...so I didn't tell anybody. I was on my own until I got a free meal from this lady, Mrs. Lansing. I told her I was an orphan, on my own. She said I could stay on, and...I did. (beat) Every night, I'd wake up, thinking they were right outside my window. Then I heard the police talking on the radio about what happened at the ranch, and I thought, for sure I can't go back now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since I didn't tell anybody what happened, I was afraid they'd blame me for those kids being dead. So I just...stayed away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what made you come forward now, after all this time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I miss my mom...I miss my dad...I just...I just want to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christine and Ybarra watch as Mr. and Mrs. Clay lead their son into their car. As they drive off, Christine finally breaks the silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Still can't believe it. Five years, case closed, everyone thinks he's dead...and there he is. (more)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him...and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and walks off into the night, as we SUPERIMPOSE: Gordon Stewart Northcott was hanged on October 2, 1935 In exchange for his cooperation and a guilty plea, Sanford Wesley Clark was sentenced to the Whittier State School for Boys for five years. Upon being released in 1934, he returned home to Canada, and was never heard from again. Upon returning to duty after his suspension, Captain J. J. Jones was demoted to Lieutenant and subsequently sued by Christine Collins in civil court. He was found guilty and fined $10,800 (equal to $125,000 in 2006 dollars). He never paid. One year after the City Council recommended the removal of the Los Angeles Chief of Police, James E Davis resigned from office and was replaced by Roy E. Steckel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cont'd) And he wouldn't be, if it wasn't for Walter. (beat) Your son did a brave thing, Mrs. Collins. You should be very proud of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't think he's still out there, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Three boys made a run for it that night, Detective. If one got out, maybe either or both of the others did too. Maybe Walter went through the same fears he did. Afraid to come home or identify himself, afraid he'd get into trouble, that people might think it was his fault. Either way, it gives me something I didn't have before tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: True Story
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Davis reclaimed that office in 1933, where he created the Red Squad, notorious for attacking Communists and their offices, but was forced to resign a second time under a cloud of police corruption. In the aftermath of the City Council hearings, the criminal justice system in California was revised to prevent women from being incarcerated or institutionalized for the crime of disagreeing with a male police officer. Strict medical procedures were set in place to prevent future abuse. In November 1929, Los Angeles Mayor George E. Cryer was voted out of office after three terms. He was later found to have been the front man for the Crawford Organized Crime Syndicate, which ran prostitution and gambling rackets throughout Southern California. For the rest of his life, Reverend Gustav A. Briegleb used his radio show to expose police misconduct and political corruption. He also published "The Layman's Handbook of Daniel." The California community of Wineville, near Riverside, became synonymous with the infamous Northcott Murder Ranch. In order to shake free of the scandal, the residents changed its name to Mira Loma. Christine Collins never stopped searching for her son. The fate of Walter Collins remains a mystery. If he was able to escape the Northcott Ranch, he would be 86 years old today.
direction.name: direction
